analyzed: anitya tā sūtram
translated: The Sutra on Impermanence

original: om namaḥ sarvajñāya //
analyzed: om namaḥ sarvajñāya
translated: Om, homage to the Omniscient One!

original: evam mayā śrutam /
analyzed: evam mayā śrutam
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyāṃ viharati sma As
analyzed: ekasmin samaye bhagavān śrāvastyām viharati sma
translated: At one time the Blessed One was dwelling in Shravasti,

original: jetavane 'nāthapiṇḍasyārāme mahatā bhikṣusaṃghena sārdham ardhatrayodaśabhir bhikṣuśataiḥ //
analyzed: jetavane nāthapiṇḍasya ārāme mahatā bhikṣu saṃghena sārdham ardha trayodaśabhiḥ bhikṣu śataiḥ
translated: in the Jeta Grove, in the garden of Anathapindika, together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhikshus.

original: tatra khalu bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayate sma /
analyzed: tatra khalu bhagavān bhikṣūn āmantrayate sma
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikshus:

original: anityatā bhikṣavaḥ sarvasaṃskārā adhruvā anāsvāsikā vipariṇāmadharmānaḥ /
analyzed: anitya tā bhikṣavaḥ sarva saṃskārāḥ adhruvāḥ anāsvāsikāḥ vipariṇāma dharmānaḥ
translated: Bhikshus, all conditioned things are impermanent, unstable, unreliable, subject to change.

original: yad yāvad bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyo 'laṃ nirvetum alaṃ viraktum alaṃ vimoktuṃ //
analyzed: yat yāvat bhikṣavaḥ sarvebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ lam nirvetum alam viraktum alam vimoktum
translated: Bhikshus, it is enough to feel revulsion towards all conditioned things, enough to feel dispassion, enough to be liberated.

original: sarveṣām sattvānāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāṃ prāṇinām āmaraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: sarveṣām sattvānām sarveṣām bhūtānām sarveṣām prāṇinām āmaraṇāntam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya āmaraṇam
translated: For all beings, all creatures, all living beings, life ends in death, there is no escape from death.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavo gṛhapatayo mahāsālakulā brāhmaṇamahāsālakulā kṣatriyo mahāsālakulā
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ gṛhapatayaḥ mahā sāla kulāḥ brāhmaṇa mahā sāla kulā kṣatriyaḥ mahā sāla kulā
translated: Bhikshus, those householders from great merchant families, great brahmin families, great warrior families,

original: āsāṃ mahādhanā mahābhogāḥ prabhūtamaṇimā niṣkamuktāvaiḍūryaśaṃkhaśilāpravālajātarūparajatavittopakaraṇāḥ
analyzed: āsām mahādhanāḥ mahā bhogāḥ prabhūta maṇimāḥ niṣka muktā vaiḍūrya śaṃkha śilā pravāla jātarūpa rajata vitta upakaraṇāḥ
translated: They are very wealthy, with abundant jewels, gold coins, pearls, lapis lazuli, conch shells, crystals, coral, gold, silver, and household goods.

original: prabhūtadhanadhānyakoṣṭhāgārasannicayāḥ prabhūtadāsidāsakarmakarapauruṣeyāḥ prabhūtamitrāmātyajñātisālohitās /
analyzed: prabhūta dhana dhānya koṣṭhāgāra sannicayāḥ prabhūta dāsi dāsa karmakara pauruṣeyāḥ prabhūta mitra amātya jñāti sālohitāḥ
translated: They have abundant wealth, grain, storehouses, and treasuries, abundant male and female servants, workers, and employees, and abundant friends, ministers, relatives, and kinsmen.

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: For them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who is born.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāś ca mūrdhnābhiṣiktā jānapadaiśvaryāsthāmavīryam anuprāptā mahāntaṃ pṛthvīmaṇḍalam abhinirjityāvasanti /
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ rājānaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ca mūrdhnā abhiṣiktāḥ jānapada aiśvarya āsthāma vīryam anuprāptāḥ mahāntam pṛthvī maṇḍalam abhinirjitya āvasanti
translated: Those who are kings, anointed kṣatriyas, who have attained lordship over the people, power, and strength, and who live after conquering a great circle of the earth, for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who is born.

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //🔽As 🔽ye 'pi te bhikṣava ṛṣayo vānaprasthāḥ pramuktaphalāhārāḥ pramuktaphalabhojinaḥ pramuktaphalena yāpanti /
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam  as  ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ ṛṣayaḥ vānaprasthāḥ pramukta phala āhārāḥ pramukta phala bhojinaḥ pramukta phalena yāpanti
translated: Those who are ascetics, forest-dwellers, who eat freely given fruits, who live on freely given fruits, who subsist on freely given fruits, for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who is born.🔽Those who are ascetics, forest-dwellers, who eat freely given leaves, who live on freely given leaves, who subsist on freely given leaves, for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who is born.

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: Those who are ascetics, forest-dwellers, who eat freely given fruits, who live on freely given fruits, who subsist on freely given fruits, for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who is born.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavaḥ kāmāvacarā devāś cāturmahārājikā devās trayastriṃśā devā yāmā devās tuṣitā devā nirmāṇaratayo devāḥ paranirmitavaśavartino
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ kāmāvacarāḥ devāḥ cāturmahārājikāḥ devāḥ trayastriṃśāḥ devāḥ yāmāḥ devāḥ tuṣitāḥ devāḥ nirmāṇaratayaḥ devāḥ paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ
translated: Those gods of the desire realm, the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the Yāma gods, the Tuṣita gods, the Nirmāṇarati gods, the Paranirmitavaśavartin gods,

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who has been born.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavo rūpino devāḥ /
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ rūpinaḥ devāḥ
translated: Those gods who have form, monks,

original: prathamadhyānalābhino brahmakāyikā brahmapurohitā brahmapārṣadyā mahābrahmāṇā /
analyzed: prathama dhyāna lābhinaḥ brahmakāyikāḥ brahmapurohitāḥ brahma pārṣadyāḥ mahābrahmāṇā
translated: who have attained the first meditation, the Brahmakāyika, Brahmapurohita, Brahmapārṣadya, Mahābrahmā gods,

original: dvitīyadhyānalābhinaḥ parittaśubhā apramāṇaśubhā ābhāsvarās /
analyzed: dvitīya dhyāna lābhinaḥ paritta śubhāḥ apramāṇa śubhāḥ ābhāsvarāḥ
translated: who have attained the second meditation, the Parīttaśubha, Apramāṇaśubha, Ābhāsvara gods,

original: tṛtīyadhyānalābhinaḥ parittaśubhā apramāṇaśubhāḥ śubhakṛtsnāś /
analyzed: tṛtīya dhyāna lābhinaḥ paritta śubhāḥ apramāṇa śubhāḥ śubha kṛtsnāḥ
translated: who have attained the third meditation, the Parīttaśubha, Apramāṇaśubha, Śubhakṛtsna gods,

original: caturthadhyānalābhino 'nabhrakāḥ puṇyaprasavā vṛhatphalā asaṃjñisattvā avṛhā As
analyzed: caturtha dhyāna lābhinaḥ nabhrakāḥ puṇya prasavāḥ vṛhat phalāḥ asaṃjñi sattvāḥ avṛhāḥ
translated: who have attained the fourth meditation, the Anabhraka, Puṇyaprasava, Bṛhatphala, Asaṃjñisattva, Avṛha,

original: atapāḥ sudarśāḥ sudarśanā akaniṣṭhāś ca devās /
analyzed: atapāḥ sudarśāḥ sudarśanāḥ akaniṣṭhāḥ ca devāḥ
translated: Atapa, Sudarśana, Akaniṣṭha gods,

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: for them too, life ends in death, ends in death, there is no immortality for one who has been born.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavo 'rūpino devā ākāśānantyāyatanopagā vijñānānantyāyatanopagā ākiṃcityāyatanopagā naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanopagāś ca devāś
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ rūpinaḥ devāḥ ākāśa ānantya āyatana upagāḥ vijñāna ānantya āyatana upagāḥ ākiṃcitya āyatana upagāḥ na eva saṃjñāna asaṃjñā āyatana upagāḥ ca devāḥ
translated: Those monks who are formless gods, gone to the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

original: teṣām api maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: teṣām api maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: even for them, life ends in death, ends in death. There is no birth for one who has died.

original: traidhātukam idaṃ //
analyzed: traidhātukam idam
translated: This is the triple world.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavo 'rhantaḥ kṣīṇāśravā kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛtakaraṇīyā apahṛtabhārā anuprāptasvakārthāḥ
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ rhantaḥ kṣīṇa āśravāḥ kṛtakṛtyāḥ kṛta karaṇīyāḥ apahṛta bhārāḥ anuprāpta svaka arthāḥ
translated: Those monks who are arhats, with outflows exhausted, who have done what had to be done, done their duties, laid down the burden, attained their own goal,

original: parikṣīṇabhavasaṃyojanāḥ samyagājñāsuvimuktacittāḥ sarvacetovasiparamapāramitāprāptās /
analyzed: parikṣīṇa bhava saṃyojanāḥ samyagājñā su vimukta cittāḥ sarva cetaḥ vasi parama pāramitā prāptāḥ
translated: with the fetters that bound them to existence completely exhausted, with their minds well liberated by right knowledge, who have attained the highest perfection of mastery over all mental states,

original: teṣām api kāyā nikṣepaṇadharmāḥ //
analyzed: teṣām api kāyāḥ nikṣepaṇa dharmāḥ
translated: even for them, this body has the nature of being laid down.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhāḥ khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpā ekam ātmānaṃ damanti ekam ātmānaṃ śamayanti ekam ātmānaṃ parinirvāpayanti /
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ pratyekabuddhāḥ khaḍga viṣāṇa kalpāḥ ekam ātmānam damanti ekam ātmānam śamayanti ekam ātmānam parinirvāpayanti
translated: Those monks who are pratyekabuddhas, solitary like a rhinoceros, who tame themselves, who calm themselves, who attain final nirvana by themselves,

original: teṣām apy ayaṃ kāyo nikṣepaṇadharmaḥ //
analyzed: teṣām api ayam kāyaḥ nikṣepaṇa dharmaḥ
translated: even for them, this body has the nature of being laid down.

original: ye 'pi te bhikṣavas tathāgatā arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhā daśabalabalinaḥ udārārṣabhāḥ samyaksiṃhanādanādinaś caturvaiśāradyaṃ /
analyzed: ye pi te bhikṣavaḥ tathāgatāḥ arhantaḥ samyaksaṃbuddhāḥ daśa bala balinaḥ udāra ārṣabhāḥ samyak siṃhanāda nādinaḥ catur vaiśāradyam
translated: Those monks, those Tathāgatas, Arhats, Perfectly Awakened Ones, who are endowed with the ten powers, are great bulls, who have roared the lion's roar of the Perfectly Awakened Ones,

original: dharmārohaṇavaiśāradyaṃ sarvadharmadeśanāvaiśāradyaṃ nirvāṇamārgāvatāraṇavaiśāradyaṃ āśravajñānaprahāṇavaiśāradyaṃ /
analyzed: dharma ārohaṇa vaiśāradyam sarva dharma deśanā vaiśāradyam nirvāṇa mārga avatāraṇa vaiśāradyam āśrava jñāna prahāṇa vaiśāradyam
translated: who have the four forms of fearlessness: fearlessness in teaching all dharmas, fearlessness in teaching the path to nirvana, fearlessness in teaching the knowledge and abandonment of defilements,

original: viśadādṛḍhanārāyaṇasaṃhatakāyās / As
analyzed: viśada a dṛḍha nārāyaṇa saṃhata kāyāḥ
translated: whose bodies are firm and solid like Nārāyaṇa's,

original: teṣām apy ayam kāyo nikṣepaṇadharmaḥ //
analyzed: teṣām api ayam kāyaḥ nikṣepaṇa dharmaḥ
translated: their bodies too are subject to being laid down.

original: tadyathāpi nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhākārakṛtāni bhāṇḍā āmāni vā pakvāni vā bhedanaparyantāni bhedanaparyavasāny /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma bhikṣavaḥ kumbhākāra kṛtāni bhāṇḍāḥ āmāni vā pakvāni vā bhedana paryantāni bhedana paryavasāni
translated: Just as, monks, all vessels made by a potter, whether unbaked or baked, are subject to breaking, end in breaking,

original: evam eva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣāṃ sattvānāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāṃ prāṇināṃ maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ maraṇaparyavasānaṃ nāsti jātasyāmaraṇaṃ //
analyzed: evam eva bhikṣavaḥ sarveṣām sattvānām sarveṣām bhūtānām sarveṣām prāṇinām maraṇa antam hi jīvitam maraṇa paryavasānam na asti jātasya amaraṇam
translated: in the same way, monks, for all beings, for all creatures, for all living beings, life ends in death, for one who is born there is no escape from death.

original: idam avocad bhagavān /
analyzed: idam avocat bhagavān
translated: This was said by the Blessed One.

original: idam uktvā sugato hy athāparāvocat śāstā /
analyzed: idam uktvā sugataḥ hi atha aparā avocat śāstā
translated: Having said this, the Well-Gone One, the Teacher, further said this:

original: anityā vata saṃskārā utpādavyayadharminaḥ /
analyzed: anityāḥ vata saṃskārāḥ utpāda vyaya dharminaḥ
translated: Impermanent, indeed, are compounded things; they arise and cease.

original: utpadya hi nirūdhyante teṣāṃ vyupaśamaḥ sukhaṃ //
analyzed: utpadya hi nirūdhyante teṣām vyupaśamaḥ sukham
translated: For what arises, ceases; the cessation of them is happiness.

original: yathāhi kumbhakāreṇa mṛttikābhājanaṃ kṛtaṃ /
analyzed: yathā hi kumbhakāreṇa mṛttikā bhājanam kṛtam
translated: Just as a potter makes clay pots,

original: sarvam bhedanaparyantaṃ sattvānāṃ jīvitaṃ tathā //
analyzed: sarvam bhedana paryantam sattvānām jīvitam tathā
translated: so is the life of beings subject to destruction.

original: yathā phalānāṃ pakvānāṃ śaśvat patanato bhayaṃ /
analyzed: yathā phalānām pakvānām śaśvat patanataḥ bhayam
translated: Just as there is always the fear of ripe fruits falling,

original: tathā saṃskārajāḥ sattvānāṃ nityaṃ maraṇato bhayaṃ //
analyzed: tathā saṃskāra jāḥ sattvānām nityam maraṇataḥ bhayam
translated: so is there always the fear of death for beings born from the elements.

original: sarve kṣayāntā nicayāḥ patanāntāḥ samucchrayāḥ /
analyzed: sarve kṣaya antāḥ nicayāḥ patana antāḥ samucchrayāḥ
translated: All accumulations end in depletion, all rising ends in falling,

original: saṃyogāś ca viyogāntā maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitaṃ //🔽As
analyzed: saṃyogāḥ ca viyoga antāḥ maraṇa antam hi jīvitam  as
translated: all unions end in separation, and all life ends in death.

original: idam avocad bhagavān āttamanas te ca bhiksavas te ca parṣado bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandan //
analyzed: idam avocat bhagavān ātta manaḥ te ca bhiksavaḥ te ca parṣadaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāṣitam abhyanandan
translated: Thus spoke the Blessed One. Delighted, those monks and that assembly rejoiced in what the Blessed One had said.

original: ity āryānityatāsūtraṃ samāptaṃ //
analyzed: iti ārya anityatā sūtram samāptam
translated: Thus concludes the Noble Discourse on Impermanence.
